90.08 Inspection of Meters,      90.19 Installation of Irrigation Equipment
Pipes and Fixtures
90.09 Opening Hydrants           90.20 Interference with Water Main or Service
                                 Pipes
90.10 Expansion of Water Mains;  90.21 Backflow Prevention
Size of Mains
90.11 Water Mains – Payment of
Costs
 
90.01 DEFINITIONS.
The following terms are defined for use in the chapters of this Code of
Ordinances relating to the water service system:
1.   “Customer” means anyone using water furnished by the City, including other
departments, funds, boards and commissions of the City.
2.   “Service pipe” means the pipe laid beyond the water main toward the
premises to be served with water. The service pipe includes all pipes and
valves between the water main and the water meter.
3.   “Water Department” means the City, acting through its qualified officers.
4.   “Water main” means any pipe laid by the Water Department or an agent
thereof, or accepted by the Water Department, which is a portion of a water
distribution system of the City.
90.02 APPLICATION FOR SERVICE.
Applications for water service shall be presented to the Building Official
together with the request for a building permit. Said building permit shall
include a statement indicating the size of the water service tap as well as the
water service size that is required, including the approximate location where
the service will enter the premises. The building permit application will
include the cost for water service material, tap and meter.
90.03 TAPS TO WATER MAINS.
All taps to water mains shall be made by the Water Department. The Water
Department shall charge a uniform fee for the making of all taps, such fee to
be based on labor, material and overhead expense. The size of each tap shall be
approved by the Water Department. A suitable area around the main, properly
protected with cribbing when necessary, shall be provided by the owner.
90.04 SERVICE PIPES.
1.   Installation of Services. All service pipes and fixtures from the street
water main to the premises, including the corporation cock, shall be installed
at the expense of the owner. All one-inch to two-inch service pipes shall be
copper pipe from the corporation cock to the stop box and from the stop box to
the building shall be of materials as specified by the Water Department. A
service may not cross another property line to supply water for the applicant.
2.   Size of Service.
   A.   Residential – one-inch minimum size from the main to street side of the
meter.
   B.   Commercial – one-inch minimum from the main to the street side of the
meter or as determined by the Water Department.
   C.   Multi-Family and Industrial – as determined by the Water Department.
All pipes requiring a service larger than two (2) inches shall be made with a
tapping sleeve and cast iron gate valve of a minimum of four (4) inches in size
and a roadway valve box of a design approved by the Water Department.
3.   Service Shutoff. The stop box and curb valve shall be of a design approved
and supplied by the Water Department at a uniform charge. A stop box on every
service shall be kept flush with the surrounding ground in a location approved
by the Water Department. The stop box and curb valve will not be installed
underneath or in a sidewalk. The water is to be turned on at the stop box only
by authorized Water Department personnel. It is unlawful for any person to
block or hinder access to the stop box.
4.   Extension of Service Pipes. After a service connection has been laid, no
plumber or other person shall make any attachment or connection thereto so as
to serve any premises or buildings other than set forth in the original
application for service.
5.   Maintenance. All service pipes and fixtures from the street water main to
the premises, including the corporation cocks and threading at the mains, shall
be the responsibility of and maintained at the expense of the owners. Any leak
or other defect in the service shall be promptly repaired by the owner, and if
not repaired promptly, the water shall be turned off until such repairs have
been made. In any case where the Water Department informs a property owner that
there is a leak in said owner’s service and the plumber finds that the leak is
actually in the main, the Water Department will reimburse the property owner
for any actual expense and will assume responsibility for the repairs.
90.05 NONCONFORMING SERVICE LINES AND CONNECTIONS.
Service lines presently in use and made of materials other than cast iron,
copper or approved plastic shall be replaced by copper, cast iron or approved
plastic pipes at the expense of the owner when, in the opinion of the Water
Department, such lines have become so disintegrated as to be unfit for further
use or if the lines contain hazardous material (i.e. lead). Owners of premises
having water services which do not have separate stop cocks and boxes for each
building or separately owned unit, or which do not otherwise conform to the
requirements of this chapter shall be required to put in such stop cocks or
make such other changes as are necessary to conform with the requirements of
this chapter when instructed to do so by the Water Department. In the event
only one unit owner on a joint water service line attempts to have separate
stop cocks and boxes, and the remaining joint users refuse to share equitably
in the total cost thereof, then upon receipt of a qualified, written, itemized,
signed appraisal showing a total cost in excess of $1,500.00, the Water
Department with City Administrator approval may accept in escrow 110% of the
pro rata user’s share of the total cost. Said escrow amount shall release that
user’s unit from the lien or cloud of nonconformance herewith. Additionally,
said escrow amount shall be non-interest-bearing and held by the City for
eventual contribution to the total cost of bringing all of the involved joint
users into compliance herewith. The Water Department does not waive its right
to a total joint line service “shut off” wherein an individual joint user has
become delinquent in service payment.
90.06 ABANDONED SERVICE PIPES.
All service pipes that may become useless because water will no longer be used
through them shall be permanently closed off at the water main at the expense
of the owner of the premises. If the service is to be replaced because of
inadequacy or for other reasons, the old service shall be shut off at the main
and the old pipe cut off at the corporation cock by the Water Department. No
plumber or property owner shall disconnect or remove water supply fixtures or
piping from any premises served by the Water Department or alter the same in
any way so as to make the service connection unnecessary for the premises
without having the Water Department permanently close off the connection at the
main. If a service pipe or connection, not currently in use, is found to be
leaking, the Water Department may, without notice, turn off the same and charge
the expense thereof to the owner of the property.
90.07 SUPPLY OF OTHER THAN CITY WATER.
On premises where water is supplied from two (2) sources, City water being one
of them, the piping system for the City water shall be entirely separate from
that of the other source, unless such other supply is approved for public use
by the Board of Health and is maintained in such approved condition. If other
than City water is to be furnished to premises previously supplied by City
water, the owner or plumber doing the work shall give notice thereof at the
office of the Water Department when such change is to be made, and provisions
shall also be made for cutting off the City water supply at the corporation
cock and disconnecting the service pipe. When the owner of the premises or an
authorized agent has a direct connection between the City water supply and
another supply which has not been approved, said owner or agent shall forthwith
disconnect the same. The owners of any houses, buildings or properties used for
human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the
City and abutting any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now
located a public water main, are prohibited from drilling any type of well for
the provision of supplying potable water to the property.
90.08 INSPECTION OF METERS, PIPES AND FIXTURES.
Any officer or employee of the Water Department or any authorized City
inspector shall be permitted at all reasonable hours to enter the premises or
buildings of customers for the purpose of reading meters and inspecting the
water pipes and fixtures. The Water Department reserves the right to set or
remove a meter whenever it is deemed advisable to do so. Refusal on the part of
the owner, customer or occupant of any premises served by City water, within
three business days of request by the Water Department, to permit an officer or
employee of the Water Department to enter such premises shall be sufficient
cause for discontinuance of water service to such premises.
90.09 OPENING HYDRANTS.
No person, except authorized City employees acting in the performance of their
duties, shall open any hydrant belonging to the Water Department at any time
without a written permit issued by the Water Department.
90.10 EXPANSION OF WATER MAINS; SIZE OF MAINS.
The size of the main required to serve any part of the City shall be determined
by the Water Department, and all plans and specifications of proposed
expansions or extensions of water mains shall be approved by the Water
Department. The Water Department shall inspect such expansions or extensions
and a fee in the amount of the hourly rate plus one hundred percent (100%)
shall be charged for such inspection.
90.11 WATER MAINS – PAYMENT OF COSTS.
When water mains are extended, the property owners benefited thereby, as
determined by the Water Department, shall be charged a uniform fee based on the
cost of extending a main eight (8) inches in diameter, together with all
necessary valves, fire hydrants and other parts.
90.12 EXTENSION OF MAINS TO PROPERTY LINES.
All water main extensions shall be made to the farthest point on the owner’s
property line in order to allow for any future expansion. Said extension shall
be ended or terminated with a fire hydrant and valve.
90.13 EXTENSION OF MAINS ON PERIMETER STREETS.
Extensions of water mains along streets lying partly inside and partly outside
the City limits may be made on the basis of special assessments against
abutting property owners. The City may pay the assessment on land lying outside
the City limits and, if so paid, the City may make provision for collecting
such payments from the abutting property owners at such time as such land may
be annexed.
90.14 CONNECTING LOOPS.
Before any abutting property shall connect to the mains constructed at the
expense of the Water Department, a charge based on the front footage of the
property to be served shall be collected by the City on the basis of the costs
of the six (6) inch main. Connecting loops and cross ties within a subdivision
shall be constructed by the subdivider. If the connecting loop is such that the
property outside the subdivision abuts such loop or ties and connections are
made to such a line, the reimbursement provisions of this chapter shall apply.
90.15 EXTENSION OF MAINS OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS.
No main shall be extended outside the City limits, except to serve property
within the City limits or under contract with the City.
90.16 SUBDIVISIONS AND DEVELOPMENTS.
When it is requested or necessary to bring water service from the existing
water system through private or vacant property, or to construct lines to the
perimeter of such property, the subdivider, developer or individual shall pay
the entire cost of the construction and shall furnish all necessary easements
or rights-of-way. This section does not preclude the City from extending water
lines by special assessment process if so determined.
90.17 CONTROL BY THE CITY.
The City reserves the right to shut off the water in its mains or in a service
line at any time when necessary for the purpose of making repairs or extensions
or for other reasons, and the City shall have the sole authority to restore
such service.
90.18 LIABILITY – RESPONSIBILITY IN TURNING ON WATER.
The City shall not be responsible or liable for any damage done to the property
of the user or owner by reason of the water service supply being shut off for
any reason, provided notice is sent to the user or owner of such property,
regardless of actual receipt thereof. In turning on water or restoring service,
the City shall not be responsible for any damage that may occur by reason of
improper fixtures, open or improper connections or for any other cause.
90.19 INSTALLATION OF IRRIGATION EQUIPMENT.
Before the installation of any equipment that is to be used for irrigation
purposes within the City’s right-of-way, the Contractor shall obtain a permit
from the Building Official and pay the appropriate fee for excavating in the
right-of-way. The City may remove, or cause to be removed, said irrigation
equipment that is located in the City’s right-of-way for any lawful purpose if
the City Engineer determines that the equipment is interfering with the
implementation of said lawful purpose. If said equipment is removed for any
lawful purpose, the City is under no obligation to replace said equipment.
90.20 INTERFERENCE WITH WATER MAIN OR SERVICE PIPES.
When the City has determined that any animate or inanimate object has
interfered with the normal operation of a water main or service pipe, said
object is deemed a nuisance, and the City shall abate said nuisance in
accordance with the provisions of
Chapter 50 of this Code of Ordinances.
90.21 BACKFLOW PREVENTION.
1.   Definitions. For use in this section, the following terms are defined:
   A.   “Approved backflow prevention assembly for containment” means a
backflow prevention assembly listed by the University of Southern California
Foundation for Cross Connection Control and Hydraulic Research as having met
the requirements of ANSI-AWWA Standard C510-89, Double Cross Valve Backflow-
Prevention Assemblies or ANSI-AWWA Standard C511-89, Reduced-Pressure Principle
Backflow-Prevention Assemblies, all as amended.
   B.   “Approved backflow prevention assembly for containment in a fire
protection system” means a backflow prevention assembly which meets the
requirements of Factory Mutual Research Corporation (FM) and Underwriters
Laboratory, in addition to the requirements of paragraph A above.
   C.   “Auxiliary water supply” means any water supply on or available to the
premises other than the approved water providers of public water, including,
but not limited to, a private well, pond or river.
   D.   “Containment” means a method of backflow prevention that requires the
installation of a backflow prevention assembly at the water service entrance.
   E.   “Cross connection” means any connection or arrangement between a
potable water supply system and any plumbing fixture or tank, receptacle,
equipment or device, through which it may be possible for non-potable, used,
unclean, polluted or contaminated water or other substance to enter into any
part of such potable water system.
   F.   “Customer” means the owner, operator or occupant of a building or a
property or of a private water system, which has a water service from a public
water system.
   G.   “Degree of hazard” means the rating of a cross connection or water
service that indicates the potential to cause contamination or pollution.
   H.   “Double check valve protection assembly” means a backflow prevention
device consisting of two independently acting, internally loaded check valves,
four properly located test plugs and two isolation valves.
   I.   “High hazard cross connection” means a cross connection which may
impair the quality of potable water by creating an actual hazard to public
health through poisoning or through contamination with sewage, industrial
fluids or waste.
   J.   “Isolation” means a method of backflow prevention in which a backflow
prevention assembly is located at the cross connection rather than at the water
service entrance.
   K.   “Low hazard cross connection” means a cross connection which may impair
the quality of potable water to a degree which does not create a hazard to
public health but which does adversely and unreasonably affect the aesthetic
qualities of such potable water for domestic use.
   L.   “Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly” means a
backflow prevention device consisting of two independently acting, internally
loaded check valves, a differential pressure relief valve, four properly
located test plugs, and two isolation valves.
   M.   “Registered backflow prevention assembly technician” means a person
registered with the Iowa State Department of Health to test or repair backflow
prevention assemblies and to report on the conditions of these assemblies.
   N.   “Thermal expansion” means the volumetric increase of water due to
hearing resulting in increased pressure in a closed system.
   O.   “Water service” means the physical connection between a public water
system and a customer’s building, property or private water system or the act
of providing potable water to a customer.
2.   Responsibility for Administration. The Building Official shall administer,
implement, and enforce the provisions of this section. Any powers granted or
duties imposed upon the Building Official may be delegated by the Building
Official to persons or entities acting in the beneficial interest of or in the
employ of the City.
3.   Right of Entry. The Building Official shall be permitted access to a
customer’s premises, upon showing proper identification or upon search warrant
by a court of appropriate jurisdiction, as often as necessary to ensure
compliance with this section.
4.   New Water Services. Prior to the issuance of a building permit, the
contractor/builder shall submit plans for a new water service to the Building
Official for review. The Building Official shall determine the type of backflow
prevention assembly required for containment based upon the degree of hazard.
The Building Official shall require the installation of the appropriate
backflow prevention assembly for containment prior to the initiation of water
service.
5.   Containment/Isolation. All customers whose premises are not classified as
single-family residential by the Building Official shall be inspected by the
Building Official to determine the type and degree of hazard to the water
system. Upon conclusion of the inspection, the Building Official shall
determine the type of backflow prevention assembly required to achieve
containment and isolation. Upon written notice, the customer, at the customer’s
own expense, shall install all backflow prevention assemblies mandated by the
Building Official.
6.   Inspection by Customer; Annual Report. Starting January 1, 2008, and each
subsequent January 1st thereafter, the customer shall submit to the Building
Official a report from a registered backflow prevention assembly technician,
certifying that containment and isolation on the customer’s premises have been
achieved.
7.   Fees. Each customer required to file an inspection report as described in
subsection 6 above shall pay an annual fee to be set by resolution of the City
Council.
CHAPTER 91
WATER METERS
 
91.01 Water Meters                91.03 Owners to Protect Meters
91.02 Metering Multi-Family Units 91.04 Testing Meters
 
91.01 WATER METERS.
1.   Water Use Metered. All water furnished customers shall be metered unless
otherwise provided for. All meters shall be purchased by permittees at the time
of receipt of a building permit and installed by a licensed plumber. Meters
shall be placed on a service pipe in a position not to exceed two (2) feet from
the location in the wall or floor where such pipe enters the premises. The
piping system shall be so constructed and the meter so placed that all water to
be used in or about the premises shall pass through the water meter. All meters
shall be set horizontally and no meter shall be set vertically.
2.   Valves and Fittings. There shall be a valve between the meter and the
wall, and a suitable place shall be provided for the meter so as to keep it
dry, clean and readily accessible at all times to the meter reader and the
inspector of the Water Department. A valve shall also be placed on the pipe on
the outlet side of each meter not more than three (3) feet from the meter. All
valves and fittings necessary to comply with this chapter to provide a
connection to the meter, except the coupling or flange at each end of the
meter, shall be provided by the owner of the premises served.
3.   Size. The Water Department reserves the right to install the size meter
that investigation shows to be sufficient to supply the quantity of water
required by the premises. For premises requiring a two (2) inch meter or
larger, the Water Department may install two (2) or more meters of a smaller
size. Where meters are so placed, each meter shall have a valve or shutoff on
both the inlet and outlet pipe, in addition to the basement shutoff. Where a
service pipe of two (2) inches or larger is used, the plumber shall contact the
Water Department for instructions regarding the fittings and space to be
provided for the water meter. The tap size, meter size and fee are as set forth
in the following table:
MAIN    TAP SIZE METER SIZE     FEE
6-inch  1-inch   5/8 x 3/4-inch $325.00
6-inch  1-inch   3/4-inch       $370.00
6-inch  1-inch   1-inch         $410.00

12-inch 2-inch   1-inch         $542.00
12-inch 2-inch   1.5-inch       $775.00
12-inch 2-inch   2-inch         $905.00
These prices include the labor for the tap, a saddle, a corporation, a curb
valve, a stop box, a meter and meter connections. For larger meters, pricing
will be determined by the Water Department on an as-needed basis.
 
4.   More Than One Meter in Building. In case two (2) or more meters are
designed to measure water to different tenants in the same building from one
service connection, they shall be placed so that no one of them will measure
water which has passed through the other one.
5.   New Buildings. If the meter is to be installed in a new building or
structure, the applicant shall furnish the Water Department proof that the
plumbing has been approved by the Plumbing Inspector, that all charges for
water previously furnished such applicant and all other charges due for
services furnished thereto have been paid and that a suitable place is provided
for the meter. The unmetered use of water during the construction of new
buildings shall be permitted; provided, however, that such use is reasonable;
and further provided that the watering of seed, sod, shrubbery, trees and all
other landscaping plantings and materials is expressly prohibited before the
proper installation of a water meter. The meter will be set and the water
turned on to the stop inside the house where the owner or occupant may turn the
water on into the piping system and fixtures of the premises. Payment for the
meter as per the above schedule shall be made at the time the building permit
is issued.
6.   Access to Water Meters Located in Secure Locations. In the event that the
water meter(s) are located at a secure location within the building, the owner,
occupant or customer shall, within three (3) business days of written notice to
said owner, occupant, or customer, permit an officer or employee of the Water
Department to access the water meters for any lawful purpose.
91.02 METERING MULTI-FAMILY UNITS.
All buildings or multi-family units containing two (2) or more units shall be
furnished with one (1) meter of a size determined by the Water Department. The
meter readings shall be billed to the owner at the current commercial rate on a
commercial schedule. At the owner’s request, meters may be purchased for each
unit, and the owners of the buildings shall be billed for the individual meter
readings on the current residential rate. The owner shall be charged for any
meters in excess of the one provided by the City. The owner may use additional
meters for private owner monitoring, which shall be purchased through the Water
Department. Meters under either provision set out in this section shall be
listed under the owner’s name and be billed to the owner.
91.03 OWNERS TO PROTECT METERS.
1.   The owner of the premises where a meter is installed shall be held
responsible for its care and protection from freezing or hot water and from
injury or interference from any person. In case of damage to the meter, or in
case of its stoppage or imperfect working, the owner of the premises shall give
immediate notice to the office of the Water Department. In all cases where
meters are broken or damaged by negligence of an owner or occupant of the
premises, or by freezing, hot water or other injuries, except ordinary wear,
the necessary repairs to the meter shall be made by the Water Department and
the cost thereof shall be paid by the owner. In case payment thereof is
neglected or abused, the Water Department shall turn off the water and shall
not turn it on until full payment, together with all service charges, has been
made. Damaged meters may be repaired by the Water Department without first
giving notice thereof to the owners of the premises served by such meters.
2.   No one shall in any way interfere with the proper registration of water
meters and no one except an authorized employee of the Water Department shall
break a seal on a meter. The City may assess the property owner or tenant a
treble charge for the estimated or metered water wrongfully obtained when
tampering has been determined by the City to have taken place.
3.   Whenever a water meter is installed on a water service in premises that
are to be remodeled, removed or destroyed, or where the service is to be
discontinued so that the water meter is no longer needed, the owner of such
premises shall give notice to the Water Department in writing to remove such
meter, and free access thereto shall be provided. The owner of the premises or
an authorized agent shall be responsible for the meter until such written
notice is given and the meter is recovered. If the meter is damaged, buried or
lost, the owner of the premises or the authorized agent shall be required to
pay for the same at cost less depreciation.
91.04 TESTING METERS.
In case there is any doubt on the part of the customer as to the accuracy of
any water meter, the customer may have the meter tested by the Water
Department, at which the customer may be present or have a representative
present if desired. If the meter is found to register within two percent (2%)
of being correct, a charge will be made to pay for the labor in making such a
test and all related service charges. If the meter is found to measure more
than two percent (2%) fast, no charge will be made therefor, and there shall be
a proportional deduction made from the last water bill preceding the test. A
water meter shall be considered to register satisfactorily when it registers
within two percent (2%) accuracy.
CHAPTER 92
WATER RATES
 
92.01 Water Rates               92.04 Notification to Install Stop Cocks and
                                Boxes
92.02 Rates Outside the City    92.05 Charges for Service Calls
92.03 Billing for Water Service
 
92.01 WATER RATES.
The water rate charged by the City is shown in Section
107.03(1) of this Code of Ordinances.
92.02 RATES OUTSIDE THE CITY.
The water rate for customers located outside the corporate limits of the City
is double the rate provided in Section
92.01. Customers shall be billed every month with a monthly minimum charge
double the minimum charge provided in Section
92.01. Council approval must be obtained prior to hookup and the same
application procedures, rules, conditions, collection and enforcement
provisions in this Code of Ordinances shall apply.
92.03 BILLING FOR WATER SERVICE.
Water service shall be billed as part of a combined service account in
accordance with Section
107.04 of this Code of Ordinances.
92.04 NOTIFICATION TO INSTALL STOP COCKS AND BOXES.
The Water Department shall notify customers, both residential and commercial,
who do not have provision for separate stop cocks and boxes as required and who
within thirty (30) days of billing date have not paid in full the regular
billing for water, that such customers or the owners of the property served
shall install the stop cock and box as required within fifteen (15) days of
notification or the same shall be done by the City and the cost thereof
assessed to the property.
92.05 CHARGES FOR SERVICE CALLS.
The Water Department shall establish a uniform charge for all service calls
made. A service charge shall be made for all necessary calls, other than for
the repair of equipment belonging to the Water Department.
CHAPTER 93
WATER CONSERVATION
 
93.01 Purpose                  93.04 Stage III – Water Emergency
93.02 Stage I – Water Watch  93.05 Enforcement and Violation
93.03 Stage II – Water Warning
 
93.01 PURPOSE.
The purpose of this chapter is to establish and set forth a plan and procedure
regarding water usage and conservation thereof in the City, in times of drought
or water shortages, that will fairly distribute the available water supplied by
the City for the use and protection based on three (3) separate stages.
93.02 STAGE I – WATER WATCH.
A water watch may be issued when water demand reaches eighty-five percent (85%)
of the water plant production capacity. Voluntary water restrictions may be
requested without mandatory restrictions and there will be public releases of
the water status.
93.03 STAGE II – WATER WARNING.
A water warning may be issued when water demand reaches ninety-five percent
(95%) of the water plant production capacity. Mandatory water restrictions will
be issued with public releases of water status.
93.04 STAGE III – WATER EMERGENCY.
A water emergency may be issued when water demand exceeds plant production
capability. Water may have to be shut off to sections of the distribution
system. Public statements or press releases will be issued.
93.05 ENFORCEMENT AND VIOLATION.
A violation of Stage II or Stage III provisions may result in a reduction of
water flow to the violator. Whether or not such a reduction of water flow is
implemented, the City may proceed in the same manner as any other violation of
this Code of Ordinances.

94.03 WATER SYSTEM UTILITY CONNECTION FEE.
A connection fee is hereby imposed for each connection made to the Municipal
Water System Utility within the boundaries of the West Coralville Water System
Connection Fee District described herein. The proposed improvements are known
as the “West Coralville Water System Extension Project” (hereinafter referred
to as the “Project Improvements”) and consist generally of the construction of
water storage and oversizing water distribution improvements from 12-inch to
18-inch in diameter to serve approximately 1,620 acres within the District. The
Project Improvements are expected to be constructed in stages as development
occurs within the District. The Plan contains a description of the Project
Improvements and an Infrastructure Map illustrating the proposed locations of
the 18-inch diameter water main extensions to be constructed. The Plan also
contains an Infrastructure Cost Estimate for the proposed Project Improvements
(the “Infrastructure Cost Estimate”) and an allocation of the same on a per-
acre basis. As of January 1, 1998, the Project Improvements were expected to
serve 1,620 acres within the District, and construction costs were estimated to
be $1,250,000. As of said date, the estimated cost per acre for such
improvements was $775.00. The Infrastructure Cost Estimate will be reviewed
annually by an engineering firm selected by the City for said purpose and
adjusted, as of January 1 of each year from and after January 1, 1998, in
accordance with the Engineering News Record Cost Index or to reflect actual
construction costs, as applicable, for the appropriate period of time and
thereafter shall be presented to the Council for approval. After approval of
the same by the Council, a copy of the most recent Infrastructure Cost
Estimate, as so adjusted, and the resulting per-acre allocation, certified by
said engineering firm, shall be available for public inspection in the office
of the Clerk during normal business hours. Each such adjusted Infrastructure
Cost Estimate shall apply and become effective for purposes of this chapter
from and after the date of the approval by the Council of the ordinance
codified in this chapter. The connection fee payable by a property owner whose
property will be served by the Project Improvements will be calculated and
imposed on a per-acre basis, including a pro rata amount for any portion of an
acre included within the owner’s subdivision plat or area to be so served and
shall be equal to (x) the most current per-acre Infrastructure Cost Estimate
for the Project Improvements approved by the Council and placed on file in the
office of the Clerk times (y) the number of acres (including any portions
thereof) included within the owner’s subdivision plat or the area to be served
by connection to the Project Improvements. The connection fee will be payable
in full at the earlier of (i) the time of submission by the property owner to
the City of the subdivision plat for the area for signature and recording by
the City, in the form approved by the Council under Section 354.8 of the Code
of Iowa, or (ii) the time of submission by the property owner to the City
Engineer of construction plans for the construction of improvements on any
portion of the owner’s property to be served by connection to the Project
Improvements. As of January 1, 1998, therefore, the connection fee payable is
$775.00 per acre of property included within the property owner’s subdivision
plat or other development area until adjusted as described above. If the owner
of two contiguous parcels affected by this chapter desires to make a connection
to the Municipal Water System Utility that will serve only one such parcel, and
the parcels do not bear common improvements and have not been assembled into a
single unit for the purpose of use or development, the owner may make
application to the Council to connect to each such parcel separately. If the
Council finds that the parcels do not bear common improvements and have not
been assembled into a single unit for the purpose of use or development, the
original connection fee shall be calculated and paid only upon the parcel or
parcels that will be served by the connection. A separate connection fee shall
be paid when the parcel or parcels not served by the original connection to the
Municipal Water System Utility are connected.
94.04 PRIVATE SYSTEMS.
Property owners within the District are not mandated to connect to the Water
System Utility if they currently have a properly operating private water
system. If a property owner’s private water system fails as determined by
guidelines previously established by the City Engineer, the property owner will
then be required to connect to the Municipal Water System Utility.
94.05 OTHER COSTS.
The connection fee imposed by this chapter is in addition to, and not in lieu
of, any other fees for connection required under the other provisions of this
Code of Ordinances. The property owner paying a connection fee will be
responsible for the full cost of providing any necessary water main extensions
or service lines from the private property improvements or buildings to the
public mains and extensions being constructed as part of the Project
Improvements.
94.06 NONPAYMENT.
In the event a connection is made to the Municipal Water System Utility without
payment of the connection fee set forth in this chapter, the City shall
disconnect such service until such time as the property owner has paid the
required connection fee. In addition, the City may pursue any other remedy
allowed by law.
94.07 USE OF PROCEEDS.
The connection fees collected by the City under this chapter shall be used only
for the purpose of operating the Municipal Water System Utility, or paying the
debt service on obligations issued to finance the Public Improvements.
94.08 INTERPRETATION.
The provisions of this chapter are intended and shall be construed so as to
fully implement the provisions of Section 384.38(3) of the Code of Iowa. In the
event that any provision of this chapter is determined to be contrary to law,
it shall not affect other provisions or application of this chapter which shall
at all times be construed to fully invoke the provisions of Section 384.38(3)
of the Code of Iowa with reference to the assessment and collection of the
connection fees provided thereunder.

gross area of property included with the owner’s subdivision plat or other
development area until adjusted as described below. Said connection fee will be
adjusted annually based upon the interest rate the City is paying for Series
2010D bonds to fund the Project Improvements. Said adjusted connection fee
shall be kept on file for public inspection by the City Clerk.

responsible for the full cost of providing any necessary water main extensions
or service lines from private property improvements or buildings to the public
mains and extensions being constructed as part of the Public Improvements.
94B.05 NONPAYMENT.
In the event a connection is made to the Municipal Water System without payment
of the connection fee set forth in this chapter, the City shall disconnect such
service until such times as the property owner has paid the required connection
fee. In addition, the City may pursue any additional remedy provided by law.
94B.06 USE OF PROCEEDS.
The connection fees collected by the City under this Chapter shall be used only
for the purpose of operating the Municipal Wastewater System Utility, or paying
the debt service on obligations issued to finance the Public Improvements.
94B.07 INTERPRETATION.
The provisions of this Chapter are intended and shall be construed so as to
fully implement the provisions of Section 384.84(3) of the Code of Iowa. In the
event that any provision of this chapter is determined to be contrary to law,
it shall not affect other provisions or application of this chapter which shall
at all times be construed to fully invoke the provisions of Section 384.84(3)
of the Code of Iowa with reference to the assessment and collection of the
connection fees provided herein.
(Ord. 2017-1012 - Dec. 17 Supp.)
SANITARY SEWER
CHAPTER 95
SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM
 
95.01 Purpose                   95.06 Service Outside the City
95.02 Definitions               95.07 Right of Entry
95.03 Superintendent            95.08 Use of Easements
95.04 Prohibited Acts           95.09 Special Penalties
95.05 Sewer Connection Required 95.10 Extension of Mains to Property Lines
 
95.01 PURPOSE.
The purpose of the chapters of this Code of Ordinances pertaining to Sanitary
Sewers is to establish rules and regulations governing the treatment and
disposal of sanitary sewage within the City in order to protect the public
health, safety and welfare.
95.02 DEFINITIONS.
For use in these chapters, unless the context specifically indicates otherwise,
the following terms are defined:
1.   “B.O.D.” (denoting Biochemical Oxygen Demand) means the quantity of oxygen
utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard
laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees C., expressed in
milligrams per liter or parts per million.
2.   “Building drain” means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a
building drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and
other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the
building sewer, beginning five (5) feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of
the building wall.
3.   “Building sewer” means that part of the horizontal piping from the
building wall to its connection with the main sewer or the primary treatment
portion of an on-site wastewater treatment and disposal system conveying the
drainage of one building site.
4.   “Combined sewer” means a sewer receiving both surface run-off and sewage.
5.   “Customer” means any person responsible for the production of domestic,
commercial or industrial waste which is directly or indirectly discharged into
the public sewer system.
6.   “Easement” means an acquired legal right for the specific use of land
owned by others.
7.   “Floatable oil” means oil, fat or grease in such a physical state that it
will separate by gravity from waste water by treatment in an approved
pretreatment facility. Waste water is considered free of floatable fat if it is
properly pretreated and does not interfere with the collection system.
8.   “Garbage” means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation,
cooking, and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of
produce.
9.   “Industrial wastes” means the liquid wastes from industrial manufacturing
processes, trade, or business as distinct from sanitary sewage.
10.   “Inspector” means the person duly authorized by the Council to inspect
and approve the installation of building sewers and their connections to the
public sewer system; and to inspect such sewage as may be discharged therefrom.
11.   “Natural outlet” means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake,
or other body of surface or groundwater.
12.   “On-site wastewater treatment and disposal system” means all equipment
and devices necessary for proper conduction, collection, storage, treatment,
and disposal of wastewater from four or fewer dwelling units or other
facilities serving the equivalent of fifteen persons (1500 gpd) or less.
13.   “pH” means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions
in grams per liter of solution.
14.   “Public sewer” means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties
have equal rights, and is controlled by public authority.
15.   “Sanitary sewage” means sewage discharging from the sanitary conveniences
of dwellings (including apartment houses and hotels), office buildings,
factories or institutions, and free from storm, surface water, and industrial
waste.
16.   “Sanitary sewer” means a sewer which carries sewage and to which storm,
surface, and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted.
17.   “Sewage” means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences,
business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with
such ground, surface, and storm waters as may be present.
18.   “Sewage treatment plant” means any arrangement of devices and structures
used for treating sewage.
19.   “Sewage works” or “sewage system” means all facilities for collecting,
pumping, treating, and disposing of sewage.
20.   “Sewer” means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage.
21.   “Sewer service charges” means any and all charges, rates or fees levied
against and payable by customers, as consideration for the servicing of said
customers by said sewer system.
22.   “Slug” means any discharge of water, sewage, or industrial waste which in
concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any
period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times
the average twenty-four (24) hour concentration or flows during normal
operation.
23.   “Storm drain” or “storm sewer” means a sewer which carries storm and
surface waters and drainage but excludes sewage and industrial wastes, other
than unpolluted cooling water.
24.   “Superintendent” means the Superintendent of sewage works and/or of water
pollution control of the City or any authorized deputy, agent, or
representative.
25.   “Suspended solids” means solids that either float on the surface of, or
are in suspension in water, sewage, or other liquids, and which are removable
by laboratory filtering.
26.   “Watercourse” means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either
continuously or intermittently.
95.03 SUPERINTENDENT.
The Superintendent shall exercise the following powers and duties:
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 372.13[4])
1.   Operation and Maintenance. Operate and maintain the City sewage system.
2.   Inspection and Tests. Conduct necessary inspections and tests to assure
compliance with the provisions of these Sanitary Sewer chapters.
3.   Records. Maintain a complete and accurate record of all sewers, sewage
connections and manholes constructed showing the location and grades thereof.
95.04 PROHIBITED ACTS.
No person shall do, or allow, any of the following:
1.   Damage Sewer System. Maliciously, willfully, or negligently break, damage,
destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or
equipment which is a part of the sewer system.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 716.1)
2.   Surface Run-off or Groundwater. Connect a roof downspout, sump pump,
exterior foundation drain, areaway drain, or other source of surface run-off or
groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected
directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer.
3.   Manholes. Open or enter any manhole of the sewer system, except by
authority of the Superintendent.
4.   Objectionable Wastes. Place or deposit in any unsanitary manner on public
or private property within the City, or in any area under the jurisdiction of
the City, any human or animal excrement, garbage, or other objectionable waste.
5.   Septic Tanks. Construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank,
cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage except
as provided in these chapters.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3f])
6.   Untreated Discharge. Discharge to any natural outlet within the City, or
in any area under its jurisdiction, any sanitary sewage, industrial wastes, or
other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in
accordance with subsequent provisions of these chapters.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3f])
7.   Covering Manholes. Deposit, or cause to be deposited, soils on top of
manhole covers.
95.05 SEWER CONNECTION REQUIRED.
The owners of any houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy,
employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the City and abutting
on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located, or may in
the future be located, a public sanitary or combined sewer, are hereby required
to install, at such owner’s expense, suitable toilet facilities therein and a
building sewer connecting such facilities directly with the proper public
sewer, and to maintain the same all in accordance with the provisions of these
Sanitary Sewer chapters, such compliance to be completed within ninety (90)
days after date of official notice from the City to do so provided that said
public sewer is located within two hundred (200) feet from any proposed
building or exterior drainage facility on any lot or premises which abuts and
is served by such public sewer and is of such design as to receive and convey
by gravity such sewage as may be conveyed to it. Billing for sanitary sewer
service will begin the date of official notice to connect to the public sewer.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12 [3f])
(IAC, 567-69.1[3])
95.06 SERVICE OUTSIDE THE CITY.
The owners of property outside the corporate limits of the City so situated
that it may be served by the City sewer system may apply to the Council for
permission to connect to the public sewer upon the terms and conditions
stipulated by resolution of the Council.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.4 [2 & 3])
95.07 RIGHT OF ENTRY.
The Superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the City bearing
proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all
properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling,
and testing in accordance with the provisions of these Sanitary Sewer chapters.
The Superintendent or representatives shall have no authority to inquire into
any processes including metallurgical, chemical, oil, refining, ceramic, paper,
or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and
source of discharge to the sewers or waterways or facilities for waste
treatment.
95.08 USE OF EASEMENTS.
The Superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the City bearing
proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private
properties through which the City holds a duly negotiated easement for the
purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement,
sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying
within said easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement,
shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement
pertaining to the private property involved.
95.09 SPECIAL PENALTIES.
The following special penalty provisions shall apply to violations of these
Sanitary Sewer chapters:
1.   Notice of Violation. Any person found to be violating any provision of
these chapters except subsections 1, 3 and 4 of Section
95.04, shall be served by the City with written notice stating the nature of
the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory
correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in
such notice, permanently cease all violations.
2.   Continuing Violations. Any person who shall continue any violation beyond
the time limit provided for in subsection 1 hereof shall be in violation of
this Code of Ordinances. Each day in which any such violation shall continue
shall be deemed a separate offense.
3.   Liability Imposed. Any person violating any of the provisions of these
chapters shall become liable to the City for any expense, loss, or damage
occasioned the City by reason of such violation.
95.10 EXTENSION OF MAINS TO PROPERTY LINES.
All sanitary sewer main extension shall be made to the farthest point on the
owner’s property line in order to allow for any future expansion.
CHAPTER 96
BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS
 
96.01 Permit Required         96.05 Inspection Required
96.02 Supervision             96.06 Property Owner’s Responsibility
96.03 Excavations             96.07 Abatement of Violations
96.04 Connection Requirements
 
96.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connection with or opening into,
use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first
obtaining a written permit from the Building Official in accordance with the
following:
1.   Application. Any person desiring to make a connection with the sewer
system shall first file with the Building Official an application therefor, on
blanks furnished by the City, setting forth the location and description of the
property to be connected with the sewer system and for what purpose the sewer
is to be used.
2.   Plans and Specifications. The permit application shall be supplemented by
any plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the
judgment of the Building Official.
3.   Inspection Fees. The application shall be accompanied by a sewer
connection inspection fee in accordance with the fee schedule established by
resolution of the Council. In the event a property has an existing sewer
connection which is disconnected by the owner for the purpose of expansion,
reconstruction or new construction, then a credit in the amount of the prior
use rate shall be allowed against the new use rate, provided the same is
accomplished within a twelve-month period.
4.   Permit Issued. When such application is approved by the Building Official
and the sewer connection inspection fee paid, a receipt and permit to make the
connection will be issued by the Building Official. In the event that there is
a denial of the permit or some other controversy, the applicant may have the
matter determined by the Council.
96.02 SUPERVISION.
All connections with the sanitary sewer system shall be made and installed as
directed by the Building Official, subject to inspection and approval before
being covered. The Building Official shall keep a record of all such
connections.
96.03 EXCAVATIONS.
All excavations required for the installation of a building sewer shall be made
in accordance with the provisions of
Chapter 135 of this Code of Ordinances.
96.04 CONNECTION REQUIREMENTS.
The installation of the building sewer and its connection to the public sewer
shall conform to the requirements of the International Plumbing Code, the laws
of the State and other applicable rules and regulations of the City.
96.05 INSPECTION REQUIRED.
No building sewer shall be covered, concealed or put into use until it has been
tested, inspected and accepted as prescribed in the International Plumbing
Code.
96.06 PROPERTY OWNER’S RESPONSIBILITY.
All costs and expenses incident to the installation, connection and maintenance
of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify
the City from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned
by the installation of the building sewer.
96.07 ABATEMENT OF VIOLATIONS.
Construction or maintenance of building sewer lines whether located upon the
private property of any owner or in the public right-of-way, which construction
or maintenance is in violation of any of the requirements of this chapter,
shall be corrected, at the owner’s expense, within thirty (30) days after date
of official notice from the Council of such violation. If not made within such
time the Council shall, in addition to the other penalties herein provided,
have the right to finish and correct the work and assess the cost thereof to
the property owner. Such assessment shall be collected with and in the same
manner as general property taxes.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3])
CHAPTER 97
USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS
 
97.01 Storm Water                    97.06 Outdoor Grease Trap Required
97.02 Surface Waters Exception       97.07 Special Facilities
97.03 Prohibited Discharges          97.08 Control Manholes
97.04 Restricted Discharges          97.09 Testing of Wastes
97.05 Restricted Discharges – Powers
 
97.01 STORM WATER.
No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any storm water, surface
water, groundwater, roof run-off, sub-surface drainage, uncontaminated cooling
water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. Storm
water and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as
are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers, or to a natural
outlet approved by the Superintendent and Building Official. Industrial cooling
water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged on approval of the
Superintendent, to a storm sewer, combined sewer, or natural outlet.
97.02 SURFACE WATERS EXCEPTION.
Special permits for discharging surface waters to a public sanitary sewer may
be issued by the Building Official upon recommendation of the Superintendent
where such discharge is deemed necessary or advisable for purposes of flushing,
but any permit so issued shall be subject to revocation at any time when deemed
to the best interests of the sewer system.
97.03 PROHIBITED DISCHARGES.
No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following
described waters or wastes to any public sewers:
1.   Flammable or Explosive Material. Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil,
or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid, or gas.
2.   Toxic or Poisonous Materials. Any waters or wastes containing toxic or
poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by
interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment
process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or
create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant,
including but not limited to cyanides in excess of two (2) milligrams per liter
as CN in the wastes as discharged to the public sewer.
3.   Corrosive Wastes. Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 6.5 or
having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to
structures, equipment, and personnel of the sewage works.
4.   Solid or Viscous Substances. Solid or viscous substances in quantities or
of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other
interference with the proper operation of the sewage works such as, but not
limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags,
feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure,
hair and fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc.,
either whole or ground by garbage grinders.
97.04 RESTRICTED DISCHARGES.
No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described
substances, materials, waters, or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of
the Superintendent and Building Official that such wastes can harm either the
sewers, sewage treatment process, or equipment, have an adverse effect on the
receiving stream or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property, or
constitute a nuisance. In forming an opinion as to the acceptability of these
wastes, the Superintendent and Building Official will give consideration to
such factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation to flows and
velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, nature of
the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant, degree of
treatability of wastes in the sewage treatment plant, and other pertinent
factors. The City has the right to set lower limits than indicated in the
following subsections if deemed necessary on a case by case basis. The
substances restricted are:
1.   High Temperature. Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one
hundred thirty (130) degrees F.
2.   Oils. Waste water containing more than twenty-five (25) milligrams per
liter of petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oils or products of mineral
oil origin.
3.   Oils, Fat, Grease. Waste water from industrial plants, restaurants,
nightclubs, hotels, motels, service stations, truck stops, etc., containing
floatable oils, fat or grease in excess of one hundred ten (110) milligrams per
liter. The property owner and/or tenant shall maintain all grease traps in
working condition. In the event that the Wastewater Superintendent, in his sole
opinion, requires jet flushing of sewer lines from the accumulation of oils,
fats or grease, the owner of the property and/or tenant which deposits said
oils, fats and/or grease must submit payment to the City for the cost of jet
flushing within 30 days of invoice of the City. In the event that the owner/
tenant does not pay within 30 days, the City Clerk may certify said amount to
the County Treasurer for collection with ordinary taxes.† 3
4.   Garbage. Any garbage that has not been properly shredded, that is, to such
a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions
normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half
(½) inch in any dimension. Garbage grinders may be connected to sanitary sewers
from homes, hotels, institutions, restaurants, hospitals, catering
establishments or similar places where garbage originates from the preparation
of food in kitchens for the purpose of consumption on the premises or when
served by caterers.
5.   Excessive B.O.D., Solids or Flow. Any waters or wastes having (1) a five
(5) day biochemical oxygen demand greater than three hundred (300) parts per
million by weight, or (2) containing more than three hundred fifty (350) parts
per million by weight of suspended solids, or (3) having an average daily flow
greater than two percent (2%) of the average sewage flow of the City, shall be
subject to the review of the Superintendent and Building Official. Where
necessary in the opinion of the Superintendent and Building Official, the owner
shall provide, at the owner’s expense, such preliminary treatment as may be
necessary to (1) reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to three hundred (300)
parts per million by weight, or (2) reduce the suspended solids to three
hundred fifty (350) parts per million by weight, or (3) control the quantities
and rates of discharge of such waters or wastes. Plans, specifications, and any
other pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment
facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the Superintendent and
Building Official and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced
until said approvals are obtained in writing.
6.   Toxic or Objectionable Wastes. Any waters or wastes containing iron,
chromium, copper, zinc, and similar objectionable or toxic substances; or
wastes exerting an excessive chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such
material received in the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds
the limits established by the Building Official and Superintendent for such
materials.
7.   Odor or Taste. Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste or
odor producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be
established by the Building Official as necessary, after treatment of the
composite sewage, to meet the requirements of state, federal, or other public
agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters.
8.   Radioactive Wastes. Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life
or concentration as may exceed limits established by the Superintendent and
Building Official in compliance with applicable State or Federal regulations.
9.   Slugs. Unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting
“slugs” as defined herein.
10.   Damaging Substances. Any waters, wastes, materials or substances which
react with water or wastes in the sewer system to release noxious gases,
develop color of undesirable intensity, form suspended solids in objectionable
concentration or create any other condition deleterious to structures and
treatment processes.
11.   Untreatable Wastes. Waters or wastes containing substances which are not
amenable to treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes employed,
or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment
plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having
jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters.
 
Notes
3 † EDITOR’S NOTE. See also Section
  97.06 – “Outdoor Grease Trap Required.”
97.05 RESTRICTED DISCHARGES - POWERS.
If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be discharged to the
public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the
characteristics enumerated in Section
97.04 and which in the judgment of the Superintendent and Building Official may
have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment, or
receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a
public nuisance, the Superintendent may:
1.   Rejection. Reject the wastes by requiring disconnection from the public
sewage system;
2.   Pretreatment. Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for
discharge to the public sewers;
3.   Controls Imposed. Require control over the quantities and rates of
discharge; and/or
4.   Special Charges. Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and
treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges under the
provisions of
Chapter 99.
97.06 OUTDOOR GREASE TRAP REQUIRED.
Prior to the issuance of an occupancy permit under the City’s Building Code,
all restaurants, as defined in
Chapter 165, shall be required to install and maintain an outside grease trap
in a manner that minimizes discharge into the City’s wastewater system. Upon
request of the Wastewater Superintendent, the owner of the restaurant shall
produce maintenance records to prove that the owner has been maintaining the
outside grease trap. In the event that the Wastewater Superintendent determines
that the grease trap is not being cleaned and maintained, or is discharging
amounts of grease into the wastewater system that could lead to damage to the
system or private property, the Wastewater Superintendent may, upon three days’
written notice, order that the outside grease trap be cleaned. In the event
that said grease trap is not cleaned within said three-day period, the
Wastewater Superintendent may have the outside grease trap cleaned and assess
the costs of the same back to the owner.
97.07 SPECIAL FACILITIES.
If the Superintendent permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows,
the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the
review and approval of the Building Official, City Engineer and State
Department of Natural Resources and subject to the requirements of all
applicable codes, ordinances, and laws. Where preliminary treatment or flow-
equalizing facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be
maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at
the owner’s expense.
97.08 CONTROL MANHOLES.
When required by the Superintendent, the owner of any property serviced by a
building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control
manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the
building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the
wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located,
and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the Building
Official. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at the owner’s expense,
and shall be maintained by the owner so as to be safe and accessible at all
times.
97.09 TESTING OF WASTES.
All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and
wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in
accordance with the latest edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of
Water and Wastewater, published by the American Public Health Association, and
shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples
taken at said control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been
required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream
manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is
connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to
reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the
existence of hazards to life, limb, and property. (The particular analyses
involved will determine whether a twenty-four (24) hour composite of all
outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples
should be taken. Normally, but not always, B.O.D. and suspended solids analyses
are obtained from twenty-four (24) hour composites of all outfalls whereas pH’s
are determined from periodic grab samples). The frequency of sampling, testing
and analysis shall be determined by the Superintendent and the cost of
sampling, testing and analysis shall be an integral part of the pretreatment
cost of surcharge in the sewer service charges.
CHAPTER 98
ON-SITE WASTEWATER SYSTEMS
 
98.01 When Prohibited             98.06 Maintenance of System
98.02 When Required               98.07 Systems Abandoned
98.03 Compliance with Regulations 98.08 Disposal of Septage
98.04 Permit Required             98.09 Minimum placeLot Area
98.05 Discharge Restrictions
 
98.01 WHEN PROHIBITED.
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, it is unlawful to construct or
maintain any on-site wastewater treatment and disposal system or other facility
intended or used for the disposal of sewage.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3f])
98.02 WHEN REQUIRED.
When a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of Section
95.05, every building wherein persons reside, congregate or are employed shall
be provided with an approved on-site wastewater treatment and disposal system
complying with the provisions of this chapter.
(IAC, 567-69.1[3])
98.03 COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATIONS.
The type, capacity, location and layout of a private on-site wastewater
treatment and disposal system shall comply with the specifications and
requirements set forth by the Iowa Administrative Code 567,
Chapter 69, and with such additional requirements as are prescribed by the
regulations of the County Board of Health.
(IAC, 567-69.1[3 & 4])
98.04 PERMIT REQUIRED.
No person shall install or alter an on-site wastewater treatment and disposal
system without first obtaining a permit from the County Board of Health.
98.05 DISCHARGE RESTRICTIONS.
It is unlawful to discharge any wastewater from an on-site wastewater treatment
and disposal system (except under an NPDES permit) to any ditch, stream, pond,
lake, natural or artificial waterway, drain tile or to the surface of the
ground.
(IAC, 567-69.1[3])
98.06 MAINTENANCE OF SYSTEM.
The owner of an on-site wastewater treatment and disposal system shall operate
and maintain the system in a sanitary manner at all times and at no expense to
the City.
98.07 SYSTEMS ABANDONED.
At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by an on-
site wastewater treatment and disposal system, as provided in Section
95.05, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with
these Sanitary Sewer chapters and the on-site wastewater treatment and disposal
system shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 364.12[3f])
98.08 DISPOSAL OF SEPTAGE.
No person shall dispose of septage from an on-site treatment system at any
location except an approved disposal site.
98.09 MINIMUM LOT AREA.
No permit shall be issued for any on-site wastewater treatment and disposal
system employing sub-surface soil absorption facilities where the area of the
lot is less than one acre.
CHAPTER 99
SEWER SERVICE CHARGES
 
99.01 Sewer Service Charges Required 99.03 Private Water Systems
99.02 Rate                           99.04 Customer Rental Rate System
 
99.01 SEWER SERVICE CHARGES REQUIRED.
Every customer shall pay to the City sewer service fees as hereinafter
provided.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.84)
99.02 RATE.
Each customer shall pay sewer service charges for the use of and for the
service supplied by the municipal sanitary sewer system based upon the amount
of water consumed as follows:
1.   Rates in the City are shown in Section
107.03(2).
2.   Hookup Outside City. Council approval must be obtained prior to hookup and
should only be granted when the property owner demonstrates that:
   A.   The hookup is necessary to bring the property at issue into compliance
with all applicable Federal, State, and local laws, rules, and regulations
pertaining to the treatment and discharge of sewage and/or environmental
contamination; and
   B.   Annexing the property into the corporate City limits is either
impossible or creates a substantial hardship to the property owner.
99.03 PRIVATE WATER SYSTEMS.
Customers whose premises are served by a private water system shall pay sewer
charges based upon the water used as determined by the City either by an
estimate agreed to by the customer or by metering the water system at the
customer’s expense. Any negotiated, or agreed upon sales or charges shall be
subject to approval of the Council.
(Code of Iowa, Sec. 384.84)
99.04 CUSTOMER RENTAL RATE SYSTEM.
All parties understand that the Customer Rental Rate System set forth in
Section
99.02 takes precedence over any terms or conditions of agreements or contracts
between the City and customers (including industrial customers, special
districts and other municipalities) which are inconsistent with the
requirements of the paragraph 567 IAC 92.10(2)(b) and CFR 35.2140 dated
February 17, 1984. Accordingly, the City will notify each customer at least
annually, in conjunction with a regular bill, of the rate being charged for
operation and maintenance costs of the sewage treatment plant, including
replacement of the treatment works.

100.03 SANITARY SEWER UTILITY CONNECTION FEE.
A connection fee is hereby imposed for each connection made to the Municipal
Sanitary Sewer Utility within the boundary of the West Coralville Sanitary
Sewer Connection Fee District described herein. The proposed improvements are
known as the “West Coralville Sanitary Sewer Extension Project” (hereinafter
referred to as the “Project Improvements”) and consist generally of the
construction of (i) certain off-site trunk sanitary sewers (referred to as the
Oakdale Trunk Sewers) to serve approximately 4,980 acres, including the
District and (ii) certain on-site trunk sanitary sewers of various diameters to
serve approximately 1,450 acres within the District. The Project Improvements
are expected to be constructed in stages as development occurs within the
District. The Plan contains a description of the Project Improvements and an
Infrastructure Map illustrating the proposed locations of the sanitary sewer
mains to be constructed. The Plan also contains an Infrastructure Cost Estimate
for the proposed Project Improvements (the “Infrastructure Cost Estimate”) and
an allocation of the same on a per-acre basis. As of January 1, 1998, the
Oakdale Trunk Sewers being constructed as part of the Project Improvements were
expected to serve 4,980 acres, including the District, and construction costs
were estimated to be $890,000. As of said date, the estimated cost per acre for
such improvements was $180.00. As of January 1, 1998, the on-site trunk
sanitary sewers being constructed as part of the Project Improvements were
expected to serve 1,450 acres, and were estimated to cost $7,526,103. The
estimated cost per-acre as of said date for such improvements was $5,200 per
acre. The Infrastructure Cost Estimate will be reviewed annually by an
engineering firm selected by the City for said purpose and adjusted, as of
January 1 of each year from and after January 1, 1998, in accordance with the
Engineering News Record Cost Index or to reflect actual construction costs, as
applicable, for the appropriate period of time and thereafter shall be
presented to the City Council for approval. After approval of the same by the
Council, a copy of the most recent Infrastructure Cost Estimate, as so
adjusted, and the resulting per-acre allocation, certified by said engineering
firm, shall be available for public inspection of the office of the City Clerk
during normal business hours. Each such adjusted Infrastructure Cost Estimate
shall apply and become effective for purposes of this chapter from and after
the date of approval by the Council of the Ordinance codified in this chapter.
The connection fee payable by a property owner whose property will be served by
the Project Improvements will be calculated and imposed on a per-acre basis,
including a pro rata amount for any portion of an acre included within the
owner’s subdivision plat or area to be so served and shall be equal to (x) the
most current per-acre Infrastructure Cost Estimate for the Project Improvements
approved by the Council and placed on file in the office of the Clerk times (y)
the number of acres including any portions thereof included within the owner’s
subdivision plat or the area to be served by connection to the Project
Improvements. The connection fee will be payable in full at the earlier of (i)
the time of submission by the property owner to the City of the subdivision
plat for the area for signature and recording by the City, in the form approved
by the Council under Section 354.8 of the Code of Iowa, or (ii) the time of
submission by the property owner to the City Engineer of construction plans for
the construction of improvements on any portion of the owner’s property to be
served by connection to the Project Improvements. As of January 1, 1998,
therefore, the connection fee payable is $5,380 per acre of property included
within the property owner’s subdivision plat or other development area until
adjusted as described above. If the owner of two contiguous parcels affected by
this chapter desires to make a connection to the Municipal Sanitary Sewer
Utility that will serve only one such parcel, and the parcels do not bear
common improvements and have not been assembled into a single unit for the
purpose of use or development, the owner may make application to the Council to
connect to each such parcel separately. If the Council finds that the parcels
do not bear common improvements and have not been assembled into a single unit
for the purpose of use or development, the original connection fee shall be
calculated and paid only upon the parcel or parcels that will be served by the
connection. A separate connection fee shall be paid when the parcel or parcels
not served by the original connection to the Municipal Sanitary Sewer Utility
are connected.
100.04 PRIVATE SYSTEMS.
Property owners within the District are not mandated to connect to the
Municipal Sanitary Sewer Utility if they currently have a properly operating
private sewer system. If a property owner’s private sewer system fails as
determined by guidelines previously established by the City Engineer, the
property owner will then be required to connect to the Municipal Sanitary Sewer
Utility.
100.05 OTHER COSTS.
The connection fee imposed by this chapter is in addition to, and not in lieu
of, any other fees for connection required under the other provisions of this
Code of Ordinances. The property owner paying a connection fee will be
responsible for the full cost of providing any necessary sanitary sewer
extensions or service lines from the private property improvements or buildings
to the trunk sewers being constructed as part of the Project Improvements.
100.06 NONPAYMENT.
In the event a connection is made to the Municipal Sanitary Sewer Utility
without payment of the connection fee set forth in this chapter, the City shall
disconnect such service until such time as the property owner has paid the
required connection fee. In addition, the City may pursue any other remedy
allowed by law.
100.07 USE OF PROCEEDS.
The connection fees collected by the City under this chapter shall be used only
for the purpose of operating the Municipal Sanitary Sewer Utility, or paying
the debt service on obligations issued to finance the Public Improvements.
100.08 INTERPRETATION.
The provisions of this chapter are intended and shall be construed so as to
fully implement the provisions of Section 384.38(3) of the Code of Iowa. In the
event that any provision of this chapter is determined to be contrary to law,
it shall not affect other provisions or application of this chapter, which
shall at all times be construed to fully invoke the provisions of Section
384.38(3) of the Code of Iowa with reference to the assessment and collection
of the connection fees provided thereunder.
