140.01 LEGISLATIVE FINDINGS.
The City Council of Coralville, Iowa, finds, determines, and declares that:
1.   Redevelopment of commercial property in the Commerce Drive-Iowa Highway
965/U.S. Highway 6 area without improvements to the street system is contrary
to the public interest.
2.   It is undesirable to wait until a significant decline in traffic service
and safety related problems occur before making improvements to the street
system in areas of significant commercial redevelopment.
3.   The City has identified specific improvements to the street system in the
Commerce Drive-Iowa Highway 965/U.S. Highway 6 area which will accommodate
redevelopment of commercial properties, and the City Council recognizes that
said improvements to the street system are necessary to promote and protect the
public health, safety and welfare.
4.   City involvement in improvements to the street system is appropriate for
streets which are designated collectors or arterials in the functional
classification of streets within Coralville.
5.   The imposition of impact fees is one of the preferred methods of ensuring
that new development bears a proportionate share of the cost of street
improvements necessary to accommodate such development.
6.   New commercial development in the Commerce Drive-Iowa Highway 965/U.S.
Highway 6 area will create demand for improvements to the street system.
7.   The fee established in Section
140.06 hereof is derived from, based upon, and does not exceed the impact
created by the new commercial development for which the fee is to be charged.
8.   The fee established by this chapter does not constitute a tax.
140.02 AUTHORITY AND APPLICABILITY.
1.   The ordinance codified in this chapter shall be known as the “Commerce
Drive-Iowa Highway 965/U.S. Highway 6 Transportation Impact Fee Ordinance.”
2.   The Council has the authority to adopt said ordinance under its Home Rule
powers, pursuant to Article 3, Section 38A of the Constitution of the State of
Iowa, and Chapter 364 of the State Code of Iowa.
3.   This chapter shall apply to all real property in the Commerce Drive-Iowa
Highway 965/U.S. Highway 6 area which is specifically designated as Parcel A,
Parcel B, and Parcel C in
Figure 1 attached hereto and incorporated by this reference.
140.03 INTENTS AND PURPOSES.
1.   This chapter is intended to assist in the implementation of the Coralville
Community Plan and the West Coralville Land Use Plan.
2.   The purpose of this chapter is to ensure that new commercial development
in the Commerce Drive-Iowa Highway 965/U.S. Highway 6 area bears a
proportionate share of the cost of capital expenditures necessary to preserve
adequate traffic service and provide safe access to properties in the Commerce
Drive-Iowa Highway 965/U.S. Highway 6 area in Coralville.
140.04 DEFINITIONS.
1.   “Fee payer” means a person applying for the issuance of a building permit
for commercial development in Parcel A, Parcel B or Parcel C in
Figure 1 attached hereto.
2.   “Capital improvement” includes land and easement acquisition, demolition,
street construction, installation of utilities, installation of traffic
signals, and construction administration, but excludes maintenance and
operating expenditures. A “capital improvement” shall also include the cost of
design, engineering, necessary consultants and financing of a capital
improvement, including debt service.
3.   “Parcel A,” “Parcel B” and “Parcel C” are areas located within the
Commerce Drive-Iowa Highway 965/U.S. Highway 6 area and are designated on the
attached
Figure 1.
140.05 TRANSPORTATION IMPACT FEE AUTHORIZED.
1.   Any person who, after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this
chapter, seeks to develop land within Parcel A, Parcel B, or Parcel C of the
Commerce Drive-Iowa Highway 965/U.S. Highway 6 area by applying for a building
permit, is hereby required to pay a Transportation Impact Fee in the manner and
amount set forth in this chapter.
2.   No new building permit requiring the payment of an impact fee pursuant to
this chapter shall be issued unless and until the Transportation Impact Fee
hereby required has been paid.
140.06 COMPUTATION OF THE AMOUNT OF THE TRANSPORTA-TION IMPACT FEE.
The impact fees imposed by this chapter are based upon current best estimates
of the capital improvement costs of the street improvements required in the
Commerce Drive-Iowa Highway 965/U.S. Highway 6 area. The total transportation
impact fees for Parcel A, Parcel B, and Parcel C are computed as follows:
Intersection #1: Iowa Highway 965/Commerce Drive:
Parcel A & Parcel B Impact Fees
Required Improvements
   Remove existing pavement   $   22,800
   Construct turn and through lanes   $   659,200
   Install traffic signal   $   78,400
   Engineering and construction administration   $   156,100
   Total Improvements   $   916,500
Calculation of Impact Fee
·   Estimated square feet GFA from 28.51 ac. Parcel A = 310,474 square feet.
·   Estimated square feet GFA from 8.09 ac. Parcel B = 88,100 square feet.
·   Estimated trip generation from Parcels A & B (C-2 Arterial Commercial
zoning): 65 trips/1,000 square feet GFA/weekday. (Source: ITE Trip Generation
Manual, Fourth Edition; average of trip rates for (814) Specialty Retail Center
and (815) Discount Store).
·   Parcel A: 310 X 65 = 20,150 estimated trip generation.
   Parcel B: 88 X 65 = 5,720 estimated trip generation.
·   Parcel A: pass-by and multi-purpose trip adjustment: .25 X 20,150 = 5,038
   Parcel B: pass-by and multi-purpose trip adjustment: .25 X 5,720 = 1,430
   Note: The pass-by and multi-purpose trip adjustment is for trips generated
that are already passing by the site on the arterial street and for multi-
purpose trips to more than one destination in the area. These factors are high
(75%) for commercial developments on an arterial street.
·   Net trip generation from Parcel A: 5,038 trips per day.
   Net trip generation from Parcel B: 1,430 trips per day.
·   Estimated build-out Hwy. 965 entering volume = 24,900.
·   Estimated build-out ramp entering volume = 8,750.
·   Additional Commerce Drive background volume = 570.
   (Source CH2M Hill technical memorandum dated August 9, 1996: Addendum to
Revised Traffic Forecast and Operational Analysis.)
·   Build-out (year 2007) estimated total intersection entering volume:
 
Highway 965 both approaches:      24,900 (61%)
Ramp approach:                    8,750  (22%)
Parcel A:                         5,038  (12%)
Parcel B:                         1,430  (4%)
Commerce drive additional volume: 570    (1%)
                                  40,688 (100%)
 
Parcel A impact fee = $916,500 X 12% = $109,980
Parcel B impact fee = $916,500 X 4% = $36,660
Commerce Drive Improvements:
Parcel A & Parcel B Impact Fees
Required Improvements
   Remove existing pavement   $   26,000
   Construct four-lane street   $   223,700
   Install utilities   $   35,800
   Install traffic signal   $   75,000
   Contingency   $   36,100
   Engineering and construction administration   $   72,100
   Total Improvements   $   468,700
Calculation of Impact Fee
Commerce Drive is functionally classified as collector street within the
Coralville street network. As a collector street it is intended that the
street’s function be split equally between traffic circulation and property
access. Although the need to add two additional lanes to Commerce Drive at this
point in time is predicated on the redevelopment of Parcels A and B according
to the C-2 Arterial Commercial zoning classification, the need for the street
to be four lanes is also impacted by the traffic circulation function within
the entire Heartland Plaza subdivision.
The property access portion of the proposed Commerce Drive improvements (fifty
percent of the total) should be split between all lots with direct access to
the proposed improvement. This consists of Parcels A and B shown in
Figure 1. The fee for each parcel should be based on total projected trip
generation.
Note: The detail for the calculation of projected trip generation from Parcels
A and B is summarized on Page 584.2.
·   Property access portion of total expense: $468,700 X 50% = $234,350.
·   Total Projected trip generation from Parcels A & B:   Parcel A = 20,150
(78%)
                        Parcel B = 5,720 (22%)
                            25,870 (100%)
Parcel A impact fee = $234,350 X 78% = $182,793
Parcel B impact fee = $234,350 X 22% = $51,557
Intersection #2: Iowa Highway 965 and U.S. Highway 6:
Parcel C Impact Fee
Required Improvements
Intersection Reconstruction
   Remove existing pavement   $   24,600
   Reconstruct intersection   $   759,700
   Install traffic signal   $   76,200
   Engineering and construction administration   $   172,100
   Subtotal Highway 965/Highway 6 intersection    $   1,032,600
Highway 965 Fifth and Sixth Lanes
   Remove existing pavement   $   19,200
   Construct fifth and sixth lanes   $   532,500
   Engineering and construction administration    $   110,300
   Subtotal fifth and sixth lanes   $   662,000.00
   Total Improvements   $   1,694,600.00
Calculation of Impact Fee
·   Estimated square feet GFA from 37.27 ac. Parcel C = 405,870 square feet.
·   Estimated trip generation from Parcel C (C-2 Arterial Commercial zoning):
65 trips/1,000 square feet GFA/weekday. (Source: ITE Trip Generation Manual
Fourth Edition; average of trip rates (814) Specialty Retail Center and (815)
Discount Store).
·   Parcel C: 406 X 65 = 26,390 estimated trip generation.
·   Parcel C: pass-by and multi-purpose trip adjustment: .25 X 26,390 = 6,597.
   Note: The pass-by and multi-purpose trip adjustment is for trips generated
that are already passing by the site on the arterial street, and for multi-
purpose trips to more than one destination in the area. These factors are high
(75%) for commercial developments on an arterial street.
·   Net trip generation from Parcel C: 6,597 trips per day.
·   Parcel C directional distribution: 80% to intersection #3; 20% to Hwy. 965
right-in/right-out.
   The directional distribution is used to estimate how the total trips
generated will be distributed to multiple access points. Parcel C will have two
access points, intersection #3 on Hwy. 6, and a right-in/right-out on Hwy. 965.
·   Net trip generation from Parcel C to intersection #3; 5,277 trips per day.
·   Net trip generation from Parcel C to Hwy. 965 right-in/right-out: 1320
trips per day.
   It is estimated 90% of Parcel C traffic using intersection #3 will travel
through the Hwy. 6/Hwy. 965 intersection. 100% of the Parcel C traffic using
the Hwy. 965 right-in/right-out will travel through the Hwy. 6/Hwy. 965
intersection.
·   Total Parcel C trip generation that will impact Hwy. 6/Hwy. 965
intersection: 6,069 vehicles per day.
·   Estimated build-out (2007) Hwy. 6/Hwy. 965 entering volume: 36,800 vehicles
per day.
   (Source: CH2M Hill technical memorandum dated August 9, 1996: Addendum to
Revised Traffic Forecast and Operational Analysis).
·   Percentage of Hwy. 6/Hwy. 965 build-out (2007) entering volume attributable
to Parcel C: 16% .
Parcel C impact fee = $1,694,600 X 16% = $271,136.
140.07 PAYMENT OF FEE.
1.   The fee payer shall pay the total transportation impact fee required by
this chapter to the City Administrator or designee prior to the issuance of a
building permit.
2.   All fees collected shall be promptly transferred for deposit in the
Commerce Drive-Iowa Highway 965/U.S. Highway 6 Transportation Impact Fee
Restricted Fund, established in Section
140.08 hereof and held there and use solely for the purposes specified in this
chapter.
140.08 TRANSPORTATION IMPACT FEE RESTRICTED FUND.
1.   There is hereby established the Commerce Drive-Iowa Highway 965/U.S.
Highway 6 Transportation Impact Fee Restricted Fund.
2.   Monies held in the Restricted Fund, including any accrued interest, shall
be used solely for the purpose of the capital improvements specified in this
chapter, and shall not be used for maintenance or operating expenses.
3.   Monies shall be expended in the order in which they are collected.
4.   In the event that bonds or similar debt instruments are used for the
construction of capital facilities for which transportation impact fees are to
be expended, monies held in the Restricted Fund may be used to pay debt service
on such bonds or similar debt instruments as capital costs.
5.   At least once each fiscal year the City Administrator or designee shall
present to the City Council an accounting of the Restricted Fund.
6.   Monies in the Restricted Fund may be used to provide refunds as provided
in Section
140.09 hereof.
7.   Monies in the Restricted Fund shall be used for the purposes enumerated
herein, exclusive of all others, and shall remain inviolate within the
Restricted Fund.
140.09 REFUND OF FEES PAID.
1.   If a building permit for which an impact fee was paid expires without
commencement of construction then the fee payer shall be entitled to a refund,
without interest, of the impact fee paid as a condition for the issuance of the
permit, except that the City shall retain 3% as an administrative fee to offset
a portion of the cost of collection and refund. The fee payer must submit an
application for such refund to the City Administrator or designee within 30
calendar days of the expiration of the permit. Failure of the fee payer to make
application for refund within said 30 days may result in forfeiture.
2.   Any funds not expended or which remain unencumbered by the end of the
calendar quarter immediately following five years from the date the impact fee
was paid shall, upon application of the fee payer or the fee payer’s successor
in interest, be returned to such fee payer with interest at the rates earned by
the Restricted Fund during such time as the fees were held in the fund,
provided the fee payer submits an application for the refund to the City
Administrator or designee within 180 calendar days of the expiration of the
five year period. As used in this subsection, funds shall be deemed
“encumbered” if the City Council has approved a contract for construction of a
designated transportation improvement within the Commerce Drive-Iowa Highway
965/U.S. Highway 6 area as specified within this chapter.
140.10 CONSTRUCTION OF STREET IMPROVEMENTS.
The transportation improvements financed in part by the transportation impact
fee shall be:
1.   Constructed in the Commerce Drive-Iowa Highway 965/U.S. Highway 6 area as
specified within this chapter.
2.   Constructed at a time and in a design at the sole discretion of the City
Council.
3.   Designed to accommodate the transportation impact of new development
within Parcel A, Parcel B, and Parcel C.
140.11 RIGHTS OF FEE PAYERS.
1.   This chapter is intended to provide fee payers reasonable traffic service
in the vicinity of Parcel A, Parcel B, and Parcel C; and safe access to Parcel
A, Parcel B, and Parcel C.
2.   The payment of the transportation impact fee does not guarantee a fee
payer a specific level of traffic service or a specific level of property
access to Parcel A, Parcel B, or Parcel C.
140.12 RIGHT TO CONSTRUCT STREET IMPROVEMENTS.
In the event that the street improvements contemplated under this chapter have
yet to be constructed, any person seeking to develop land within Parcel A,
Parcel B, or Parcel C may elect, subject to City Council approval, to construct
at their expense those applicable street improvements that may legally be
constructed by non-governmental entities to City standards and in accordance
with plans and specifications that have been reviewed and approved by the City
Engineer as an alternative to paying the full amount of impact fees that
otherwise would be required under this chapter.
140.13 MISCELLANEOUS.
1.   The computation of the transportation impact fees shall be reviewed and
amended, if necessary, as directed by the City Council to ensure accuracy of
the estimates and projections.
2.   Calculation of transportation impact fees and the receipt hereof by the
City shall be documented in a form recordable in the office of the Johnson
County Recorder.
140.14 PENALTY.
A violation of this chapter shall constitute a municipal infraction punishable
under
Chapter 4 of this Code of Ordinances; however, in addition to or in lieu of any
prosecution, the City shall have the power to sue for relief in a civil court
to enforce the provisions of this chapter. Knowingly furnishing false
information to the City Administrator or designee, the building official, or
any municipal official who is charged with the administration of this chapter
on any matter relating to the administration of this chapter shall also
constitute a violation thereof.
